questions.text: Identify the visual field defect from the given image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A blind spot enlargement occurs when the physiological blind spot (corresponding to the optic nerve head) increases in size, often due to optic nerve or retinal disorders.

  • Common Causes of Blind Spot Enlargement:
    • Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH)
    • Inflammatory or infectious diseases: Syphilis, West Nile virus, rubella vaccination
    • Papilledema (increased intracranial pressure)
    • Optic disc drusen

Explanation for other options:

Altitudinal defect (Option A): An altitudinal defect involves loss of vision in the upper or lower half of the visual field, commonly seen in ischemic optic neuropathy (ION) or branch retinal artery occlusion (BRAO).

  • Unlike blind spot enlargement, it respects the horizontal midline.

Roenne's nasal step (Option B): This defect occurs in glaucoma, appearing as a nasal step-shaped loss in the visual field due to retinal nerve fibre layer damage. It is different from blind spot enlargement, which affects the optic nerve head region rather than a specific sector of the visual field.

Arcuate scotoma (Option D): Arcuate scotomas follow the distribution of the nerve fibre layer and are seen in glaucoma or optic neuropathies. They extend from the blind spot but do not primarily cause its enlargement.

Key Takeaway:

Papilloedema:

  • Swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure
  • Characteristic Features:
    • Passive oedema without inflammation.
    • Swelling primarily in the optic nerve head in front of the lamina cribrosa.
    • Engorged, tortuous small blood vessels and swollen nerve fibres.
    • Axoplasmic stasis with swollen, disrupted mitochondria.
    • Retinal changes include macular star and cotton-wool spots.
  • Signs:
    • Initial blurring of optic disc margins.
    • Enlargement of the blind spot due to the separation of the retina.
    • Hyperaemia, swelling, and engorgement of disc vessels.
    • Potential for haemorrhages, exudates, and macular star formation.
    • Chronic cases may lead to optic atrophy and visual loss.

Reference:

  1. Blind spot enlargement: A differential diagnosis
  2. Artefactual uniocular altitudinal visual field defect - PMC
  3. Open Angle Glaucoma - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with a gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. What is the most likely diagnosis based on fundoscopy findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image given above is retinitis pigmentosa fundoscopy findings showing a pale waxy disc, bony spicules, and attenuation of arteries.

  • Nyctalopia is one of the symptoms of retinitis pigmentosa, but it is not included in the triad.
  • The Triad of retinitis pigmentosa includes a pale, waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a dystrophy of rods and cones. Initially, rods are affected.
  • Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy.
  • It can be sporadic (40-50%) or hereditary.
  • If hereditary, autosomal dominant is the most common mode of inheritance, followed by autosomal recessive (AR). X-linked recessive inheritance is the least severe form.

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Nyctalopia (night blindness)
  • Peripheral visual field loss
  • Mid-peripheral superior scotoma leads to ring/ doughnut scotoma, resulting in tubular/ tunnel vision.

Signs:

  • Triad of a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Tapetal reflex: shining reflex at macula - seen in female carriers of XLR inheritance.

Atypical Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Atypical retinitis pigmentosa includes heterogeneous disorders that share clinical features with typical pigmentary retinal dystrophy.
  • Conditions included are:
    • RP sine pigmento - absence or paucity of pigment accumulation
    • Retinitis punctata albescens - scattered whitish-yellow spots with arteriolar attenuation, usually sparing the macula.
    • Sectoral RP - only inferior quadrants are involved.

Explanation for other options:

Retinal haemorrhage (Option B): Retinal haemorrhages occur in vascular disorders like diabetic or hypertensive retinopathy. They do not cause progressive night blindness or peripheral vision loss.

Diabetic retinopathy (Option C): Diabetic retinopathy presents with microaneurysms, haemorrhages, exudates, and neovascularisation. It primarily causes central vision loss (e.g., macular oedema) rather than peripheral vision loss.

Hypertensive retinopathy (Option D): Fundoscopic findings include flame-shaped haemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and arteriolar narrowing. It does not cause progressive night blindness or peripheral vision loss.

Key Takeaway:

Systemic associations in Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Refsum's disease: It is a defect in phytanic acid metabolism. RP+ Cerebellar ataxia+ Polyneuropathy. It is managed with a low phytanic acid diet.
  • Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome (m/c): involves RP, mental retardation, obesity, polydactyly, and paraplegia.
  • Usher's syndrome: It is retinitis pigmentosa (RP) with Sensory neural deafness.
  • Kearns-Sayer syndrome involves RP, heart block, and chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO).
  • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome involves RP, acanthocytosis, abetalipoproteinemia, and ataxia. It is managed with a low-fat diet and vitamin supplements.

Ocular associations in Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Keratoconus
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC)
  • Open-angle glaucoma (OAG)
  • Cystoid mmacular oedema(CME)

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560777/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560805/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK525980/

questions.text: A patient undergoing the Worth 4 Dot Test reports seeing only three green dots. What does this finding most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

If the patient only sees three green dots, it suggests suppression of the right eye, as the red lens over the right eye would normally allow them to see the red dot. The fact that only green dots are seen indicates that the right eye is not contributing to vision.

Worth's Four Dot Test

The patient wears goggles with red lenses in front of the right eye and green lenses in front of the left eye and views a box with 4 lights - one red, two green and one white.

Results are interpreted as below:

  • Normal binocular single vision: Patient sees all four lights in the absence of manifest squint (image A).
  • Abnormal retinal correspondence: Patient sees all four lights even in the presence of a manifest squint.
  • Left eye suppression (Option B): Patient sees only two red lights (image B).
  • Right eye suppression (Option A): Patient sees only three green lights (image C).
  • Alternating suppression: The Patient sees three green lights and two red lights, alternately.
  • Diplopia (Option C and D): Patient sees 5 lights (2 red and 3 green) (image D & E).
    • Crossed diplopia (exotropia) → Red dots seen on the left
    • Uncrossed diplopia (esotropia) → Red dots seen on the right

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image is suggestive of a Limbal dermoid.

Key Features of Limbal Dermoid:

  • Congenital lesion (often present since birth)
  • Located at the limbus (junction of cornea and sclera)
  • Non-progressive
  • May contain hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and connective tissue

Explanation for other options:

Pterygium (Option A): A pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular growth that extends onto the cornea, often due to UV exposure. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is progressive and vascularised.

Pyogenic Granuloma (Option C): Pyogenic granuloma is a vascular, red, pedunculated lesion that occurs after trauma or surgery. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is acquired and highly vascularised.

Pinguecula (Option D): A small, yellowish, raised lesion on the bulbar conjunctiva, usually near the limbus but not encroaching onto the cornea. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is acquired due to UV exposure and is seen in the elderly.

Reference:

  1. New Grading System for Limbal Dermoid: A Retrospective Analysis of 261 Cases Over10 Years

questions.text: A patient reports progressive visual decline three years following ocular surgery and presents with the condition shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is a common complication after cataract surgery.

  • It occurs when the posterior capsule of the lens becomes opacified, leading to decreased visual acuity and glare, particularly at night.
  • The symptoms of glare and decreased visual acuity, along with the fact that the patient has had cataract surgery within the last year, make PCO the most probable diagnosis.

Explanation for other options:

Pseudo-bullous keratopathy (Option A): This condition is due to endothelial dysfunction, leading to corneal oedema and bullae formation. Unlike PCO, it presents earlier and is associated with pain and photophobia rather than progressive vision loss.

Corneal dystrophy (Option B): Corneal dystrophies are bilateral, progressive, and hereditary corneal disorders affecting various corneal layers. They do not occur secondary to cataract surgery.

Posterior subcapsular cataract (Option C): PSC affects the posterior lens but occurs before cataract surgery, whereas PCO develops after cataract surgery.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK574505/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557865/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539699/

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden decrease in vision, photophobia, circumcorneal congestion, and a visible hypopyon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of sudden vision loss, photophobia (difficulty looking at light), circumcorneal congestion, and hypopyon strongly suggests acute anterior uveitis.

  • Anterior uveitis is characterised by the presence of fine, grey keratic precipitates (KPs) on the corneal endothelium, a hazy anterior chamber (aqueous flare), and a constricted pupil.

Anterior Uveitis

Definition: The most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humour; this area is known as Arlt's triangle
  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Oedema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from the inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to a festooned-shaped pupil
  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

Explanation for other options:

Acute conjunctivitis (Option A): Conjunctivitis typically presents with diffuse conjunctival redness, watery/mucoid discharge, and itching (especially in allergic conjunctivitis).

Acute angle closure glaucoma (Option B): Presents with severe ocular pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision with halos around lights. The eye appears hazy with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil, not a hypopyon. IOP is significantly elevated (>40 mmHg), which is a distinguishing feature.

Episcleritis (Option C): Episcleritis causes localised redness without circumcorneal congestion or hypopyon. It is not associated with vision loss or photophobia.

questions.text: What are the findings seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Herbert pits are depressions or pits at the limbus, seen in trachoma. They result from the resolution of limbal follicles in chronic Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

Explanation for other options:

Horner-Trantas spots (Option A): These are white, chalky dots seen at the limbus in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They represent eosinophilic collections in an allergic response. They do not form pits but rather appear as elevated spots.

Pannus (Option C): Pannus is a subepithelial fibrovascular tissue growth over the cornea. Commonly seen in trachoma and contact lens-related hypoxia.

Corneal dystrophy (Option D): Corneal dystrophies are bilateral, inherited, progressive opacities affecting different corneal layers. Examples include Reis-Bücklers dystrophy (Bowman's layer) and Macular corneal dystrophy (stroma).

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the ophthalmology outpatient department with the condition shown. What is the most appropriate course of management in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The scenario is suggestive of Bilateral congenital cataracts. Delaying surgery in cases of significant cataract can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) due to sensory deprivation.

Explanation for other options:

Medical management (Option A):

  • Delaying surgery in cases of significant cataract can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) due to sensory deprivation.
  • Medical management is only supportive and not the primary treatment.

Surgery after 6 months (Option C): Delaying surgery for 6 months can lead to irreversible visual impairment due to deprivation amblyopia.

Surgery after 2 years (Option D): Waiting until 2 years would result in severe amblyopia, making visual rehabilitation nearly impossible.
